element_texts.text: Completed

Record of Expedition
Commanded by Lt. Col Brown
12th Mo. Calvary? vol.
In Jan. & February 1860?
Completed

Page 1.

Page 1
JOURNAL
of
Expedition against hostile Indians
in
Southern Nebraska
Commanded by.
Lieut Col. R. H. Brown. 12th Mo. Cav. Vols.
January and February,
[1865 and] 1866
Completed

Page 3

The troops sent out by the Major General Commanding District of Nebraska against hostill Indians (who have for over a year past threatened the lives of emigrants travellers and freighters to and from the country West of the Missouri River on the Overland Stage Road) left Post Cottonwood Nebraska 95 miles west of Fort Kerney. on the 6th day of January. 1866 in obedience to orders from Head.Quarters.East.Sub. District of Nebraska.
The command was composed of the following Companies and Regiments viz.:
Companies A."E"T"G" and I. 1th Regiment Nebraska. Cavalry. V.V. Detachment of Co A 2th? Cav. U.S.A. and Co. A. of the Pawnee Scouts: (an Indian Company) composing the 1th Battalion Commanded by Major Thomas. J. Majors. 1th Nebraska. Cav. V.V.
Companies. A" C" D" E" G" and H" of the 7th Iowa Cav. Vols. composing the 2th Battalion Commanded by Captain. John Wilcox. Co B." 7th Iowa Cavalry. Vols. 
Companies DEFGKL and M" 12th Missouri: Cavalry. Vols. Co.K" 6th U.S. Vols. Inft and detachment of 18th U.S.O? Commanded by Captain. Charles Ernst. 12th Missouri. Cav. Vols.
Two 12 pound Mountain H--awitzers (bronze) with complement of men from Co K" 6th U.S.Vols.
Commanded by Lieut Charles Strong 6th U.S.Vols. 
It being thought necessary to travel over mountainous, rough ground while on Expedition 60 pack mules and Saddles were taken with command, each
Completed

Page 4

mule loaded with two sacks of corn but this was found to be a nuisance, and in fact delayed the command to such an extent on the first day's march, as to cause Lieut Col. Brown Commanding Expedition to dispense with any further service from the Mules, and sent back to Cottotnwood for transportation for Corn, which left scattered along the route, wherever a Mule happened to fall down with it, and had it taken from his back. The Mules were used in the teams until command arrived at Republican River, where they were sent back to Cottonwood.
This proves the inefficiency of Mules for packing purposes in winter time when snow is one the ground, and especially when the Mules are unused to being packed and starting out with an Expedition over rough, hilly, ground.

Expedition against Hostile
Sioux and Cheyenne Indians.
6th day of Jan 1966.
In accordance with instructions received from Head Quarters. East. Sub. District of Nebraska, on the 6th day of January, 1866, and preceding up Cottonwood Canon a Range Canon (or ravine) the mouth of which joins the Prairie Bottom of the Platte River, some 200 yards South of Fort Cottonwood, and one mile from the Platte River. Marched up the canon some 12 miles to the head of same, and then ascending the steep bluff at the head, struck a high divide (or high hilly ridge dividing one canon from another.)
Completed

This divide is some 7 miles long running due South. Crossed divide and struck the timber on head of Medicine Creek, no water being found at the head of the same. Marched some 2 1/2 miles down the creek, which runs S.S.E. and finding sufficient water in holes, for use of command and plenty of fuel, consisting of Box Elder, went into camp on East side of creek. Distance marched to day 22 miles arrived in camp at 7:30.P.M.
January 7th 1866
Left camp at daylight, and experienced some trouble in getting the train up the bluffs bordering creek. After succeeding in arriving all safe at top of Bluff, moved South of South East following course of creek on top of high divides. Nothing worthy of note during day. Struck Mitchells Fork of Medicine Creek at 4 P.M. and camped on same. During night a light snow fell, not very cold. Wood and Water good and abundant. Distance travelled 22 miles.
January 8th 1866
Left camp at 5 a.m. and 1/2 mile up creek bridged same and crossed all safe. Ascended bluff and marched due South for 2 1/2 and struck a small creek, wattered  in holes. Water tasting very bad, and which the Indians called in the Pawnee language, Bucks=sca=dee creek (signifying long hair the name assigned one of the Officers accompanying Expedition on account of the unusual length of his hair. Built a very good bridge across creek and then struck a high level divide runing with the Medicine. Struck Rankins Fork of Medicine and went into camp and bridged the creek. Wood and Water very
Completed

Page 6

good and abundant. So far we have had good grazing for our stock both on the hills and in the Valleys of the Medicine. Distance marched 9 1/2 miles.
January 9th 1866
Page 6 Started at 5.A.M. through a dense fog so dense that we could not see a man 50 paces from us, and which continued all day. Our guides were unable to see the  road which was very indistinct any how on account of its age no wagon having passed over it since the last Expedition went out. Marched blindly for some ten miles, having to move around the head of several small canons, which we were unable to see until close upon the edge of same. Finally struck medicine creek at a point only 3 miles distant from our camp of the previous night, and seeing that nothing could be accomplished by this marching through a heavy fog, but too wear out and exhaust our mules and Horses, concluded to go into camp. Wood and Water and grazing good and abundant.
January 10th 1866.
Morning clear and pleasant. Marched at daybreak and ascending bluffs to divid or ridge. marched some four miles and struck a small creek which we were forced to bridge- Experienced some difficult in crossing and was delayed some time. Then marched some Six miles in a direction due South and struck Medicin Creek, and being rather late went into camp. Wood and Water and grazing good and plentiful. Distance marched 10 miles. Rather cold.
January 11th 1866
Morning again very foggy. Started at daybreak and
Completed

Page 7

ascending bluffs. which here approach very cloas to the creek marched some 6 1/2 miles in a direction E.N.E. around the head of a small creek running into the Medicine, and the banks of which were perpendicular, and very high, so that grading and bridging were intirely out of the question. We then marched 9 miles in a direction due South, then East six miles farther heading another dry creek. Was now on a high mountainous ridge and as far s the eye could reach nothing but ridge after ridge broken in places by huge gorges in the heads of which grew closely together innumerable cedar trees, whose tops failed to reach as high as the tops of the precipitous banks, Then at times as we made a turn in our course, deep long and beautiful Valleys presented to the eye one of natures grandest scenes. One could hardly walk up the hillside  bordering these Valleys without experincing great fatigue so high are they. Thus continued valley's and hills. The vallies tending Toward the Republican River south, We came in sight of the Republican at 12:30P.M. and were greatly deceived in the distance to it, suposing we could down the ridge which has a gradual descent from this point to the Republican and we thought in all probability that a march of 3 or 4 miles would strike the Republican River. But we marched 4 miles and then 4 more miles and then found ourself only at the foot of the bluffs. and after crossing a broad fertile valley over which roamed vast herds of Buffalo, at a distance of 1 1/2 miles from the Bluffs struck the River and went into camp in a thick growth of willows, at 3:30 P.M. a violent wind storm set in and the
Completed

Page 8
weather suddenly turned very cold. We had plenty of dry wood, and our close proximity to the River of course could not leave us without an abundance of water. our men here had a plenty of Buffalo meet, and our Horses and Mules relished the luxurient bottom grass so lately feasted upon by the wild cattle of the prairie. Fog accasionally lifted during the day for an hour or more at a time, but always came back again. When the wind storm came up the fog gave way and the King of the prairie held full sway, greatly to our detriment.
January 12th 1866
!My Birth day! This morning Col Brown went down to the Republican and taking but few men with him. left command in camp until he could select a better spot for camping command and establish a supply base, returned in hour and a half and moved camp from the mouth of the Medicine Creek. to a point 5 miles East and down the River. to a grove of large Cottonwood trees, close to the River and encamped between a ridge of sand hills and the River. We were here sheltered on all sides from the winds and inclement weather having the timber on the River. South. the timber East and West of us and the sand hills on the North side. Here the River bottom is some two miles wide and grazing splended. Across the River on a low piece of ground is a large grove of dead timbers standing which furnishes fuel for our commanding abundance. The River is frozen over hard and teems can cross? with heavy loads. Our camp has been named in honor of Genl Coundy? Dist Camp
Completed

Page 9
Wheaton. Our stock is in very good condition now and men in fine spirits. will put detail to work building stone house for 20.M.? and C.S.? and hospital use. Day very cold.
January 13th 1866
At day break sent out four parties to scout for Indian village viz. 1 Sergt and 14 men of 7th Iowa Cavalry. Citizen John Nelson as guide. one Scout of 15 men to Blackwater. Citizen Callahan and Citizen Williams as guides. One Scout of 11 men of 1st Nebraska Cav. to the two Beavers Creeks no guide. Co. A. Powell? Scouts Lieut James Murie. commanding. followed a trail of Indians found in the vicinity immediately on our arrival here. Our supply train was unloaded and sent back to Cottonwood for supplies. under escort of a Lieutenant and 20 men who is/ instruction were to proceed as far as Rankins Creek and their camp and let train go to Cottonwood. These men are to furnish escort for all trains coming and going and furnish men for Courier duty.
January 14th 1866
Placed fatigue details at work building store house and Hospital the work is under the charge of Capt John Wilcox. 7th Iowa Cav. Nothing of any importance transpired with foregoing exceptions, weather modarate
January 15th 1866
Sent Courier to Cottonwood forwarded map of route thus far taken and Journal of events up to date. weather very cold. Hospital and Q.M. store progressing.
January 16th 1866
Fatigue detail still at work. Courier from Cottonwood
Completed

Page 10
arrived, bringing mail. Train left Cottonwood. (or rather) is to leave on the 18th.
January 17th 1866
All scouting parties returned except 11 men of 1st Nebraska. Lieut Murie. found some 80 Sioux Indians on the Blackwater 50 miles S.S.West of camp Wheaton and the scouting parties having remained together up to that creek were able to stand a small fight. Finding after two hours fighting that no advantage could be gained over the Indians and having no man killed concluded to fall back toward camp Wheaton. The Indians followed some 15 miles fireing into Murie party whenever an opportunity presented itself. One Horse shot in six places rather seriously hurt but was brought into camp and will recover in time. Indians lost one Poney killed. Of the loss of the enemy nothing known. Other party not heard from. Very cold.
January 18th 1866
Nothing of interest, Hospital and Q.M. Store nearly completed, Nothing until January 23rd 1866
January 23, 1866
Sergt Abe Hills, 1st Nebraska Cav- and Private Rolla 7th Iowa Cav voluntered to go out S. West. and endeaver to find a village of Indians. Col commanding allowed them to go, and offered to let all men who wished to go with them to go if Hiles wished them to, but the two men felt confidant of succys by going alone, and accordingly, took a pack mule and 5 days rations and at 10.30 A.M. started. Lieut Belden?1st Nebraska Cav. then proposed to take John Nelson Citizen guide, and two Indian Soldiers. and go on same mission and was allowed to go. Taking with him Private
Completed

Page11
Henry Shadbolt? Co F. and Jacob Painskey. Co.E. 1st Nebraska Cav. They started at 12.M. and crossing the River at Camp Wheaton, moved up on south side of River to a point opposite mouth of Medicine Creek and then moved South. Nothing of any moment until 29th
January 29th 1866
George Hiles returned this morning and was afoot and alone, and so foot sore and exhausted is to be unable for farther duty on expedition. He reported having gone with Rolla as far south West as forks of the Blackwater where they were attacked early on the morning of the 26th by some 30 Indians, who came suddenly upon them, as they were about leaving Camp Rolla was shot and fell, and was left by Hiles, who had one foot in the stirrup preparatory to mounting when the attack was made and who mounted and run for life, pursued by the Indians. After runing about ten miles pursued by the Indians on both sides and in the near fireing upon him continually for the first 5 or 6 miles. he finally outran them, and running over a hill and down into the valley on the other side before the Indians reached the hill. Here his Horse stumbled and fell, almost exhausted, Hiles quickly unbuckled the girth and left the Horse and hid himself in one of the numerous chasms or gullys near the Blackwater. The Indians did not come over the hill but left off the persuit, just at the right moment for Hiles. who came into Camp Wheaton after travelling all day on the 27th 28th and night of the 28th arriving in camp on morning of the 29th. Rolla supposed to be killed, in fact Hiles says he knows he is. Sent out Capt Craigler and 30 men as a [reinforcement for direct
Completed

Page 12
Belden to fall back upon. Knowing that he cannot be far from the spot where Rolla was killed, and that the Indians would be on the search for more men, crossed all the teams of the supply train to south side of River. preparatory to moving in the morning. Lieut Belden and party arrived at 3.30 P.M. all safe and bringing Hiles Horse with them and report having scouted all creeks as far as the Prairie Dog creek which they did not go to. but only in sight of it. Had found 4 or 5 day old signs of a party of 30 or 40 Indians, but could not tell which way they had gone. Snow very deep. South of Republican. Had encamped on Blackwater near first fork, and was eating breakfast on the morning of the 16th when a rattling fire of musketry or small arms fell upon their ears, apparently some 5 or 6 miles up the River. Lieut Belden who thought some party of Indians were hunting Buffalo above him on the creek concluded to leave pack mule and all heavy baggage in camp. and take all the party and go up creek and find out what caused the fireing. So sending the two Soldiers on South side of creek and himself and Nelson taking up the North side they travelled 20 miles before seeing anything suspicious. when Nelson stoped rather suddenly and motioned Lieut Belden to him. and the two keeping behind a small ledge of clay bank at foot of bluffs near the stream looked to the timber on same and saw a Horse which appeared to be frightened, and who kept throwing his about and senting the air, as if persued. Not knowing but that their was Indians near at hand. Lieut B. concluded to remain where he was. and watch the
Completed

page 13
Horse and the timber on the creek for a while feeling confident of solving the matter of the fireing of the morning. In a short time Lieut. B. saw the two soldiers comeing up the bluffs on the opposite side of the creek and who immediately upon seeing the Horse crouched down and also watched him. Shadbolt soon approached nearer the timber, and upon getting a closer view of the Horse recognized him as Hiles Horse, and called him by name,  (Selem)?? when the Horse ran to him. Lieut. Belden, and Nelson then went down to the creek, and the four came to the? conclusion that the Horse which had nothing  but his? halter on him, had broken loose and ran away from Hiles. while they were in camp or out killing a Buffalo, and concluded to go farther up the creek expecting to meet Hiles or Rolla, searching for the Horse after going some 4 or 5 miles farther up, they came suddenly upon numerous Poneys tracks freshly made that morning, and that put a different light on the subject. It was then supposed the Indians had either captured Hiles and Rolla. or they were still running from them, as indications of Indians were of a very large party to large for two men to contend against but they saw neither the bodies of Rolla or Hiles, and hoped no harm had befallen them. Knowing that the Indians who were probably chasing Hiles and Rolla would soon return to look for the Horse Lieut Belden and party went back to their camp and staid their untill the next morning. They had heard small arms fireing at the distance of 23 or 24 miles, thus proving the truth of the assuntions of our guides.
Completed

page 14
that a gunshot when fired on a timbered creek where the bluffs are high on boath? sides, Lieut Belden started with his party for Camp Wheaton. Thinking it advisable to inform Col Brown commanding Expedition of the Horse and finding Indians signs so near. and on the morning of the 29th meet Capt Craigler and squad. who were on the march between Little Beaver and Big Beaver creek, Capt Crigler went on to Blackwater. and Lieut. B. and party went on to Camp Wheaton.
January 30th 1866
Command left at Daylight, and takeing the trail of Lieut Nurie?. (and which Lieut Belden came back on) marched to the Little Beaver, distant 12 miles. The country between the Republican and the Little Beaver is like one large mound running lengthwise E and W and broken on the S. and N. by gullies and ridges which gradually desends from the top of the mound to the River on each side. thus we traveled 6 miles all the way up hill. and from their had as gradual a descent for 6 miles farther to the Little Beaver. The Little Beaver is a fork of the Big Beaver which latter runs into the Republican 18 miles below the mouth of the Medicine and is about 6 or 8 foot from the level of its banks in depth. The bottom of sand and mud alternately. and at this time but 3 feet of water in it. Experienced some delay in crossing. Fine grass on boath sides of creek just on edge of banks of same, Box Alder growing in some places along the stream very thick, at others scattering trees. Valley of the creek some 1/2 mile wide. creek very
Completed

Page 15
winding and tortuous. At 10.40 A.M. crossed it the last time. and moved up the hill on South side of creek and marched over country of same discription as that between Reppublican and Little Beaver. Marched 8 miles and struck Big Beaver. Here met Capt Craigler and his party who had bridged the creek and gone into camp their. Crossed command to South side of creek and went into camp Distance marched 20 miles. Weather pleasant. The Big Beaver is a great deel larger than The Little Beaver. Its banks some 40 or so feet in hight, and very pricipitious. Water is from 5 to 8 feet bottom Sandy. The timber of which their is any quantity. Mostly Lyme? and oak, with a great quantity of Box Elder. Buffalo very plentiful on South side of Big Beaver. 
January 31th 1866
Moved at daylight and marched over same kind of country as day before in a direction due South, for 7½ miles to top of divide. Then 2 miles West then 7½ South again. Struck the Blackwater at 3.30 P.M. and built a bridge over same and went into camp on South side. Weather fine. Snow rather deep. Marched today 17 miles. The Blackwater is in discription the same as Big Beaver, boath? very winding and grazing excellent, the wild Rye being some 8 feet long on the creeks bank and quite green. Wood and water good and in any quantity. for a command of even 2000 men if needed. Valley some ½ mile wide in places 1 mile
February 1th 1866
Started at 6.30 A.M. and moved almost due South verging West marched over country of same discription as that travelled over yesterday for 15 miles to the bottom of
Completed

Page 16
Prairie Dog Creek where we grazed our stock while Pioneer detail built a good bridge over creek. When conpleted crossed and camped on South side. Buffalo in large hirds seen to day. The country between the Blackwater and Prairie Dog, being of the same discription as that of yesterday's march is different in only one respect. being more rough and broken near the creek. Weather rather cool in evening. We are now as near as can be South of Camp Wheaton.
February 2the 1866
Left camp before daylight, and keeping as near West as the nature of the ground would permit, went around the Head of the North fork of the Solomon, and crossed Bow Creek near its head waters. The head of North Fork of the Solomon is 8 miles from Prairie Dog Creek. and Bow Creek 4 miles from North fork of Solomon. After crossing Bow creek, we marched 8 miles farther south and struck south fork on Main Solomon River. marched along the River banks East one mile to enable us to get down the bank to a camping ground. The banks of the River are close to the water some places the banks being perpendicular 70 or 80 feet to the water's edge camped between a high bluff some 40 or 50 feet high and the River in a small Oak and Cottonwood grove where a large party of Indians had encamped about two weeks before, and whose trail led to the East, down the River on the North side. Rather very cold. Snowing a little in the evening, and high wind. This evening about sundown a Large Buffalo Bull
Completed

Page 17
came to the edge of the high bluff above us (close under whose perpendicular sides we were encamped) and looked down apparently quite astonished to see such a large crowd of straingers where he wished to come down to drink. Some two or three Carbin shots caused him to turn back. and 15 or 20 of the Pawnee Indians ran up a cut or gully washed out of the bank by rain, and as they came to the top of the bluff, the Buffalo came back again and as the Indians stuck their heads over the edge of the bluff expecting to see the Buffalo running away (and each eager for a shot at him) they found themselves within three or four feet of Mr Buffalo's nose, and it was very amusing to see the Pawnee's throw themselves backward down the bluff expecting the Buffalo to come down onto them instantly, and each one scrambling for his life. The Buffalo did come down and a perfect volley was poured into him, to prevent him from running through the camp but he lived long enough to run his emense head under a Horse which was tied to a tree in his path and one toss of his head raised the Horse clear off the ground ripping him open and makeing it necessary to shoot him immediately to end his sufferings. The Buffalo went but 8 or 10 feet further and fell dead. The grazing on Solomon is very poor on the North side. The River is about 20 feet wide, and deep in places. with sandy bottom. Timber only in groves sometimes 5 or 6 miles apart. Cold
Completed

Page 18
February 3th 1866
Moved camp down the River where we could find more protection from the intensely cold weather. Found a place in a grove some 18 miles distant East. Plenty of fallen timber felled by the Indians for the purpose of feeding their Poneys on the banks of the small branches. Towards evening very cold and windy. The grazing is very poor here being nothing but coarse dead bottom grass.
Febuary 4th 1866
Sent all the teams back to wheaton and dividing what forage and rations we had among the men of the command. who were to carry them on their Horses. and curtailing the amount of bedding? so as to make the load as light as possible. We moved down the River 1½ miles, to a better camping ground, as the snow had obliterated the trail. and it was useless to march down the River a mile further without knowing we were on the right trail. Wood and water plentiful. Buffalo roaming in small heards on the hills of the opposite side of River.
Febuary 5th 1866
Marched at daybreak and the weather haveing moderated some what marched on the trail some 12½ miles. The trail is so hidden that it is only by sending men 1 or 2 miles ahead to search for the trail. and which only could be found by looking for it in bare places where the snow was blown off the tops of the ridges or slight elevation in the bottom. At the distance of 12½ miles from camp the trail divided. and one band continued down the North side of Solomon. and the other party crossed the River. We were at 10.A.M. forced to go into camp in the nearest timber to prevent men and Horses from absolutely freezing.
Completed

Page 19
while marching. Sent out a Scout of 12 men and one guide South to search for trail. and at 4.30.P.M. They returned haveing failed to find it.
Febuary 6th 1866
Col. Brown. Major Wilcox. and some 12 men started west this morning. to search for the trail which was supposed to be on the North side of River yet. They found the trail where the Indians had recrossed to the North side of Solomon again and had gone up North on a small tribuary of the Solomon where they crossed devide running East and West to the head of Bow Creek. (or very near the head) thence to Prairie Dog creek. where they formed a very large camp. It appears from the signs of the Village or encampment here that another still larger party was in camp here and the party whose trail we followed down the Solomon had joined them here. Signs were only 6 or 7 days old and the number encamped there had been estimated at 3000 or 4000 in number. Their trail which was followed some miles by order of Col Brown. Showed that they had gone North.West. by West. up the  Prairie Dog Creek and it was supposed that the party with whom Lieut Murie had been engaged were a party from this same force of Indians, and that they had gone still farther West. We went into camp on North side of Prairie Dog creek 4 miles above the Indian camp. Wood and Water good, grazing splendid. Weather very much more pleasant than yesterday. We have this day marched about 20 miles.
Febuary 7th 1866
Left camp at Daylight and crossing the trail which here ran (about a mile from the creek) parrallel with the creek,
Completed

Page 20
our rations and forage being very near exhausted and haveing not enough to last us to Camp Wheaton. we took was near a route as passiple for the purpose of intersecting the trail made by the wagons when on their way in to Camp Wheaton. Marched 15 miles and struck Blackwater at our former camping ground on that creek The weather is pleasant to day. Left 3 or 4 horses on the road to day exhausted and nearly starved. It is now necessary to move as fast as our Horses will permit of being ridden for Camp Wheaton or we will nearly all be dismounted in one day. Horses are to tired to graze. The men have picked up all the corn lying around on the ground, (where our Horses were fed when moving South) for the purpose of keeping up the strength of their Horses as much as possible. 
Febuary 8th 1866
Moved early in morning and marched 15 miles on our old trail to Big Beaver and went into camp. Left two more Horses on the road to day. They were however brought into camp late this evening. 
Febuary 9th 1866
Moved at daylight. on our old road to Little Beaver. 8 miles and their grazed our Horses two hours. Saddled again and moved 12 miles to Republican River striking it at Camp Wheaton moved up the River one mile to a point where we could cross. The ice is very rotten and a good many Horses broke through. A wagon train could not cross here now. Reached Camp Wheaton at 5.45.P.M. Horses and men very tired. Have found some corn and rations. which were in very good time to save command from starving.
Completed

Page 21
Febuary 10th 1866
Still at Camp Wheaton. Weather cold. Snowing at 3.30P.M.
Febuary 11th 1866.
Some 4 inches of snow on the ground. Cold.
Febuary 12th 1866
Left Camp Wheaton this morning at 8.A.M. weather intensely cold. The high winds from the North blowing the snow in our faces. This is colder than any day we have yet had. Marched but 23 miles to day and camped  on Medicine creek. near our old camp on our way South. Very cold to night.
Febuary 13th 1866
Left camp at day light, and taking old wagon road marched 25 miles through the coldest day we have had it being colder than yesterday. Several of our men have their hands and feet frozen. The men of the Battery once while on the march turned back with the cannon and were going back to the creek to get out of the cold wind. But I forced them to continue on the road. and we went into camp on Medicine creek at 3.15.P.M. Col. Brown and his Adjuant Thomas Porter went on to cottonwood, to transact Expeditionry busness, haveing command and encamped here under command of Major Thomas J. Majors. 1th Nebraska Vet Cavry Vols. Remained in camp untill Febuary 16th
Febuary 16th 1866
This morning at 2.O'Clock. A.M. a party of Indians some 40 of them leaving their Poneys on the south west side of Medicine creek, crossed afoot. and coming up to our camp for the purpose of stampeding and steeling our Horses most likely. But they were fired upon by the pickets. and the Indians returned the fire and threw a few rifle ball
Completed

Page 22
into the fires around Head Quarters Tent and over the battery and then ran for their Poneys and were soon gone. It was imposamible to pursue them. The night being very dark. Their being no moon. and knowing nothing of the Indians position or number, sent out a party this morning.
Febuary 17th 1866
And found that the Indians were a small foraging party. who were out Horsestealing and that they had gone over to Red Willows. creek. Left camp at 8.30. A.M. and marched to head of Medicine creek, and went into camp at a distance of 15 miles from our last night's camp. Wood and Water good and abundant for our command.
Febuary 18
Left camp before daylight and marched on our old trail. arrived at Post Cottonwood at 11.30 A.M. Feb 19th.
Febuary 19th 1866
Col. R.H. Brown. this day received orders from Sub. Dist- Head. Quarters assigning the companies who had been under his command on the expedition to stations on the Overland Stage Road. Before leaving camp where the Indians fired on us we sent trains to Camp Wheaton under charge of Lieut Dye A.A.Q.M. with Captain Clark and 25 men of the 12th Mo. Cav. for the purpose of bringing the Government stores and property left their in charge of Captain Griffith 6th U.S. Vols. when the command took up our line of march for Cottonwood. The train left camp before we started for Cottonwood. Up to date Feb 19th they have not yet arrived at Cottonwood
Completed

Page 23
Thus ends the expedition sent out by The Major General Commanding District. Every effort was used to find and punish the Indians. but without success. The command has been in the field Forty Four days. and haveing marched under unfavorable circumstances, a distance of 300 miles. haveing sent out scouting parties who traveled over 294 miles haveing scouted all the streams South of Platte River as far as Solomon Fork, and haveing lost one man killed. Three Horses lost on the Road by derserting them, one Horse killed by a Buffalo, and five horses died of overwork and disease. 
All of which is most respectfully submited for information of my Wife and friends in Buffalo. N. York.
Charles Strong
Lieut in command of Artilery
